Nazi Policies Toward Jews and Minorities

abstract.p: Helmut N Friedlaender letter sees parallels between Roger Cohen's April 30 article on Austrian politician Jorg Haider and New York Times' 1930 and 1931 reports on Adolf Hitler/

block.p: In the German election of September 1930, the Nazis obtained 30 percent of the vote. In the following couple of years, articles in your files should show the same kind of reporting on Hitler as Cohen's on Haider. After all, Neville Chamberlain and quite a few others wanted to be convinced that Hitler was not such a bad fellow.
Haider is not Hitler, but there are many parallels in your article to the situation in 1930 and 1931. The Europeans are trying to prevent untoward consequences.

Correction: June 25, 2000, Sunday A letter to the editor on May 21 in response to an article on April 30 about JRated PG-13rg Haider, leader of the Freedom Party in Austria, misstated the percentage of votes won by the Nazi Party in German elections in September 1930. It was 18 percent, not 30.
